pair.t: Violent video games do not increase aggression
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: A 2005 University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign study found Violent video games players were not statistically different from the non playing control group in their beliefs on aggression after playing the game than they were before playing and He added Nor was game play a predictor of aggressive behaviors and Compared with the control group the players neither increased their argumentative behaviors after game play nor were significantly more likely to argue with their friends and partners
pair.h: Violent video games do not increase aggression

pair.t: Some youth have tried to emulate violence in games
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: A few years ago on Long Island six teenagers were arrested after a crime spree involving breakins a violent mugging and a carjacking attempt and According to what the teens told authorities they had been trying to live out the life of Niko Belic and Ever heard of him He is the protagonist in the wildly popular video game Grand Theft Auto IV and What the teens did represents one of the worst case scenarios imagined by those who advocate for government to limit the sale of violent video games to minors
pair.h: Some youth have tried to emulate violence in games

pair.t: Youth playing violent games exhibit more aggression
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: In experimental studies children who view violent television shows or films — or who play violent video games — are significantly more likely to behave aggressively in comparison to children who view nonviolent television shows or films or who play nonviolent video games and In long term studies individuals who consume violent media during childhood end up more aggressive as adults in comparison with peers who consume nonviolent media during childhood
pair.h: Youth playing violent games exhibit more aggression

pair.t: People know video game violence is fake
pair.h: Youth playing violent games exhibit more aggression

pair.t: Young people know it as one 13 year old said during a study I conducted at Harvard With video games you know it s fake
pair.h: People know video game violence is fake

pair.t: F and B and I and data shows that youth violence continues to decline and It is now at its lowest rate in years and Violent video games therefore can hardly be seen as a major problem since they ve been around for years
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: TV violence is more harmful than violent video games and The New York Times and June 27 2011 there is much better evidence to support psychological harm from exposure to violence on TV news
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: Games help develop youths minds skills confidence and Such games in moderation may actually have some positive effects on developing minds
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: Violent video games are real danger to young minds
pair.h: Games help develop youths minds skills confidence and Such games in moderation may actually have some positive effects on developing minds

pair.t: Research studies have yielded the conclusion that the effect of violent media consumption on aggressive behavior is in the same ballpark statistically as the effect of smoking on lung cancer the effect of lead exposure on children s intellectual development and the effect of asbestos on laryngeal cancer
pair.h: Violent video games are real danger to young minds

pair.t: Psychological studies purporting to show a connection between exposure to violent video games and harmful effects on children do not prove that such exposure causes minors to act aggressively and Any demon strated effects are both small and indistinguishable from effects pro duced by other media
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: Justice Breyer Unlike the majority and I would find sufficient grounds in these studies and expert opinions for this court to defer to an elected legislature s conclusion that violent video games are particularly likely to harm children
pair.h: Violent games make youth more agressive violent

pair.t: China s one child policy is key to stabilizing global population growth and With 1 and 3 billion people a fifth of the world s population China must be a major part of the solution to the global population crisis
pair.h: China s one child policy is the key to control China s population

pair.t: China is home to more than one fifth of the world s population and It thoroughly understands the responsibility it bears in stabilizing world population growth and the essential role it should play and Family planning as an effective solution to China s population problems is more than just responsibility towards the well being of the Chinese people and future generations it is a duty owed to maintaining the stability of the world population
pair.h: China s one child policy is key to stabilizing global population growth and With 1 and 3 billion people a fifth of the world s population China must be a major part of the solution to the global population crisis

pair.t: China would have far too many children if not for one child and China estimates that it has three to four hundred million fewer people today with the one child policy than it would have had otherwise
pair.h: China s one child policy is the key to control China s population

pair.t: Condoms sex ed better population control than one child and Countries that simply improved access to contraceptives Thailand and Indonesia for instance did as much to reduce fertility as China with its draconian policies
pair.h: China would have far too many children if not for one child and China estimates that it has three to four hundred million fewer people today with the one child policy than it would have had otherwise

pair.t: India achieved stabilization without population control and There are ways to achieve population size sustainability without implementing a one child policy and There are alternative means
pair.h: China would have far too many children if not for one child and China estimates that it has three to four hundred million fewer people today with the one child policy than it would have had otherwise

pair.t: Ending China s one child policy would cause a population spike and Today the fertility level in China is around 1 and 7 children per woman and if China were to relax its one child policy then it s reasonable to expect that fertility would rise and If fertility increased to replacement level of 2 and 1 an increase of just under a half a child which is not unreasonable given desired family size the country s annual number of births would increase by nearly 30 percent or approximately five million additional births and By midcentury this would add up to nearly a quarter billion more Chinese than currently projected by the U and N
pair.h: China would have far too many children if not for one child and China estimates that it has three to four hundred million fewer people today with the one child policy than it would have had otherwise

pair.t: One child is only partly responsible for reducing China s fertility rates and The most dramatic decrease in the rate actually occurred before the policy was imposed and Between 1970 and 1979 the largely voluntary late long few policy which called for later childbearing greater spacing between children and fewer children had already resulted in a halving of the total fertility rate from 5 and 9 to 2 and 9 and After the one child policy was introduced there was a more gradual fall in the rate until 1995 and it has more or less stabilized at approximately 1 and 7 since then
pair.h: China s one child policy is the key to control China s population

pair.t: China one child forestalls problems associated with overpopulation and The reduction in fertility rate and thus population size reduced the severity of problems that come with overpopulation like epidemics slums overwhelmed social services health education law enforcement and more and strain on the ecosystem from abuse of fertile land and production of high volumes of waste
pair.h: China s one child policy is the key to control China s population

pair.t: One child changed tradition that more children is better and Professor Wang says China s family planning policies since 1978 have helped reduce the fertility rate further and contributed to a change in attitudes and A lot of people simply don t want that many children and People have accepted the policy he says
pair.h: China s one child policy is the key to control China s population

pair.t: Solid population growth in China is a good thing and A rising population is a feature of a healthy society not the beginning of the end for this sceptered land and Of course an increasing population puts pressure on any number of public facilities and services from transport to schools to housing to hospitals and But it s also a motor for future economic growth which will provide for all of this
pair.h: One child changed tradition that more children is better and Professor Wang says China s family planning policies since 1978 have helped reduce the fertility rate further and contributed to a change in attitudes and A lot of people simply don t want that many children and People have accepted the policy he says

pair.t: In 1992 the World Health Organization s Expert Committee on Drug Dependence ECDD undertook a prereview of coca leaf at its 28th meeting and The 28th ECDD report concluded that the coca leaf is appropriately scheduled as a narcotic under the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs 1961 since cocaine is readily extractable from the leaf and This ease of extraction makes coca and cocaine inextricably linked and Therefore because cocaine is defined as a narcotic coca must also be defined in this way
pair.h: Coca can be classified as a narcotic

pair.t: Coca in its natural state is not a narcotic and What is absurd about the 1961 convention is that it considers the coca leaf in its natural unaltered state to be a narcotic and The paste or the concentrate that is extracted from the coca leaf commonly known as cocaine is indeed a narcotic but the plant itself is not
pair.h: In 1992 the World Health Organization s Expert Committee on Drug Dependence ECDD undertook a prereview of coca leaf at its 28th meeting and The 28th ECDD report concluded that the coca leaf is appropriately scheduled as a narcotic under the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs 1961 since cocaine is readily extractable from the leaf and This ease of extraction makes coca and cocaine inextricably linked and Therefore because cocaine is defined as a narcotic coca must also be defined in this way

pair.t: Coca is not cocaine and Coca is distinct from cocaine and Coca is a natural leaf with very mild effects when chewed and Cocaine is a highly processed and concentrated drug using derivatives from coca
pair.h: Coca can be classified as a narcotic

pair.t: Coca cannot be disassociated with cocaine and The active ingredient in coca leaf is the same as in cocaine and It s just more concentrated in cocaine and Because the raw material of coca and its more potent relative cocaine are so closely aligned it is impossible to disassociate the two and If one hopes to consider cocaine a narcotic and stop its spread they must also forbid coca
pair.h: Coca is not cocaine and Coca is distinct from cocaine and Coca is a natural leaf with very mild effects when chewed and Cocaine is a highly processed and concentrated drug using derivatives from coca

pair.t: Component parts of other drugs aren t banned and The raw component parts of other drugs like meth are not banned and These components are a variety of household cleaning compounds and Similarly it is wrong to ban coca because it can be turned into cocaine
pair.h: Coca cannot be disassociated with cocaine and The active ingredient in coca leaf is the same as in cocaine and It s just more concentrated in cocaine and Because the raw material of coca and its more potent relative cocaine are so closely aligned it is impossible to disassociate the two and If one hopes to consider cocaine a narcotic and stop its spread they must also forbid coca

pair.t: Coca has no negative health effects
pair.h: Coca can be classified as a narcotic

pair.t: The World Health Organization found in 1995 that the use of coca leaves appears to have no negative health effects and has positive therapeutic sacred and social functions for indigenous Andean populations
pair.h: Coca has no negative health effects

pair.t: Chewing coca offers an energy boost and Coca provides an energy boost for working or for combating fatigue and cold
pair.h: Coca has no negative health effects

pair.t: Chewing coca has therapeutic value for various ailments and Chewed or consumed as tea coca counters altitude sickness aids digestion and quells hunger and fatigue
pair.h: Coca has no negative health effects

pair.t: Coca chewing is bad for human health and The decision to ban coca chewing fifty years ago was based on a 1950 report elaborated by the UN Commission of Inquiry on the Coca Leaf with a mandate from ECOSOC We believe that the daily inveterate use of coca leaves by chewing is thoroughly noxious and therefore detrimental
pair.h: Coca has no negative health effects

pair.t: Coca chewing can help relieve hunger fight obesity and Because coca helps suppress one s appetite it is also a means of combating overeating and obesity
pair.h: Coca has no negative health effects

pair.t: Unlike nicotine or caffeine coca chewing causes no harm to human health nor addiction or altered state and it is effective in the struggle against obesity a major problem in many modern societies
pair.h: Coca chewing is bad for human health and The decision to ban coca chewing fifty years ago was based on a 1950 report elaborated by the UN Commission of Inquiry on the Coca Leaf with a mandate from ECOSOC We believe that the daily inveterate use of coca leaves by chewing is thoroughly noxious and therefore detrimental

pair.t: Coca is not like caffeine nicotine due to alternative use and Again coca is unique from other substances like caffeine or nicotine in its capacity to be diverted to highly potent dangerous and damaging use in cocaine and this would justify its classification as a narcotic
pair.h: Coca can be classified as a narcotic

pair.t: Cocaine is most produced where coca is legal and Wherever coca is legally produced cocaine production thrives with greater success and The correlation is very clear and In Bolivia coca eradication efforts in the 1980s and 90s helped reduce cocaine production and As Evo Morales took power and legalized coca production and consumption however cocaine production has shot up and This is despite his efforts to fight cocaine production and The bottom line is that legalizing coca makes it easier for cocaine producers to operate and This correlation cannot be ignored
pair.h: Coca can be classified as a narcotic

pair.t: Beauty pageants teach kids to be their very best and The promoters of Australia s first Universal Royalty Beauty Pagean defended the practice saying that it taught the lesson of striving to be your very best
pair.h: Child beauty contests teach good life lessons

pair.t: Beauty contests can boost a child s self esteem and The most cited reason parents give for putting their children into beauty pageants is to boost their child s self esteem as well as teach poise public speaking skills tact and confidence
pair.h: Child beauty contests teach good life lessons

pair.t: Claiming let alone believing an arena where very young children are primped like mini adults and pitted against each other in a bid to decide who s the prettiest is good for confidence or self esteem is to dwell in a fool s paradise
pair.h: Beauty contests can boost a child s self esteem and The most cited reason parents give for putting their children into beauty pageants is to boost their child’s self esteem as well as teach poise public speaking skills tact and confidence

pair.t: Beauty pageants foster destructive perfectionism self criticism and William Pinsof a clinical psychologist and president of the Family Institute at Northwestern University Being a little Barbie doll says your body has to be a certain way and your hair has to be a certain way and In girls particularly this can unleash a whole complex of destructive self experiences that can lead to eating disorders and all kinds of body distortions in terms of body image
pair.h: Beauty contests can boost a child s self esteem and The most cited reason parents give for putting their children into beauty pageants is to boost their child’s self esteem as well as teach poise public speaking skills tact and confidence

pair.t: Child beauty pageants judge whole person and Some of the criteria considered in judging a pageant are writing skills interviews personality looks confidence and talent depending on the specific competition
pair.h: Child beauty contests teach good life lessons

pair.t: Child beauty contests teaches there will always be somebody better and Another child beauty contest mother noted I want my child to be aware that there s always going to be somebody better than her and It s a hard thing to learn – it was for me – and I want her to start early
pair.h: Child beauty contests teach good life lessons

pair.t: Pageants teach that self worth is in physical beauty only and Melinda Tankard Reist one of the founders of Collective Shout Competing in these events very young children are taught very early that their only value comes from their appearance and the way they look and This in turn leads to emotional problems eating disorders and a distorted sense of self worth and self esteem
pair.h: Child beauty pageants judge whole person and Some of the criteria considered in judging a pageant are writing skills interviews personality looks confidence and talent depending on the specific competition

pair.t: Child beauty contests help teach kids to deal with competition
pair.h: Child beauty contests teach good life lessons

pair.t: Pageants teach kids to follow rules and play fair and In these cases child pageants can teach kids to be gracious winners and good losers and They ll learn the aspects of rules and fair play
pair.h: Child beauty contests help teach kids to deal with competition

pair.t: Better alternatives to beauty pageants for building character and Anything good that a pageant does for a child something else does it better and As a former basketball player and competitive cheerleader yes it s a sport I know that competition and the wins and losses that went with it educated me about the real world and But it s exactly because I did those self esteem building activities that I know there are options for parents who want confident happy kids
pair.h: Child beauty contests help teach kids to deal with competition

pair.t: Beauty contests teach kids how to strive to move up and You see this a lot among people on the lower income and education scales and They want their kids to learn skills that are needed to move up the social scale
pair.h: Child beauty contests teach good life lessons

pair.t: Fawzi Bukatif the commander of the Martyr s Brigade part of the forces battling Gaddafi said the rebels progress was hampered by a lack of weapons and a reliance on old Russian weapons and The problem we have is we have run out of weapons he said and You know our weapons are traditional ones the old ones the Russian weapons and We need ammunition and We need new weapons and We need anti tanks we do not have facilities but we have the soldiers left behind by Gaddafi and If we do have weapons and ammunitions that we need at the moment we can move strongly and faster
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: At the end of the day it s entirely possible that giving Libyan rebels a boost in arms could at a minimum level the playing field with respect to Gaddafi forces
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: Once Gaddafi realizes that he is up against an endless supply of arms and ammunition he will surely recalibrate his decisions and There have been reports that he floated the idea of leaving office as long as he is guaranteed safe passage
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: West should protect Libyan civilians not arm rebels and NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen says the coalition under his control is clear about its mission and We are not in Libya to arm people and We are in Libya to protect civilians against attacks
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: Arms will go to rebels no matter if West provides them and There are strong arguments for providing at least small arms and One reason is that weapons are probably going to pour in anyway perhaps from Egyptian stockpiles or factories and perhaps paid for by Gulf Arab states indeed the Wall Street Journal has reported that this is already happening though Egypt denies it
pair.h: West should protect Libyan civilians not arm rebels and NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen says the coalition under his control is clear about its mission and We are not in Libya to arm people and We are in Libya to protect civilians against attacks

pair.t: Humanitarian mission needn t involve arming Libyan rebels and It might be justifiable to arm the rebels if that were only way to achieve the humanitarian objectives of the intervention and Yet there isn t any evidence that it would be necessary to do so to defend Benghazi as a sanctuary and It seems clear that Benghazi can be defended from the air by NATO even if that requires enforcing no drive zones occasionally
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: The rebels don t need arms so much as technical and tactical training in how to use them the creation of some kind of communications network and a command structure that might help them become a cohesive fighting force
pair.h: At the end of the day it s entirely possible that giving the rebels a boost in arms could at a minimum level the playing field with respect to Gaddafi forces

pair.t: No controls on how Libyan rebels use West s weapons and Now the Administration s policy may be migrating toward the idea of supplying the rebels with weapons and Yet the rebels have as yet no command and control they serve a political entity if that is not too generous a way to describe the councils that have been set up in eastern Libya that is recognized as legitimate by France alone and There is no way to police the rebels conduct or to hold them accountable for their actions on the battlefield
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: The alternative to arming the rebels is almost certainly many thousands executed and thousands more disappeared by Gaddafi s military and secret police though
pair.h: Arming Libyan rebels has a military impact on the rebels combat abilities and in ousting Gaddafi from power

pair.t: Random breath tests help deter drunk driving and A 1995 review by the European Transport Safety Council concluded There is wide agreement in the international scientific literature that increasing driver s perception of the risk of being detected for excess alcohol is a very important element in any package of measures to reduce alcohol related crashes
pair.h: Random sobriety tests for drivers are effective at deterring drunk driving

pair.t: Random breath testing doesn t necessarily lower drunk driving and Many countries have had random testing for some time and have seen no real fall in drink driving figures
pair.h: Random sobriety tests for drivers are effective at deterring drunk driving

pair.t: Little evidence random alcohol tests deter drunk driving and There is a dearth of research regarding the deterrent effect of checkpoints and The only formally documented research regarding deterrence is a survey of Maryland s Checkpoint Strikeforce program and The survey found no deterrent effect To date there is no evidence to indicate that this campaign which involves a number of sobriety checkpoints and media activities to promote these efforts has had any impact on public perceptions driver behaviors or alcohol related motor vehicle crashes and injuries and This conclusion is drawn after examining statistics for alcohol related crashes police citations for impaired driving and public perceptions of alcohol impaired driving risk
pair.h: Random breath testing doesn t necessarily lower drunk driving and Many countries have had random testing for some time and have seen no real fall in drink driving figures

pair.t: Random alcohol breath tests reduce accidents save lives and The Centers for Disease Control in a 2002 Traffic Injury Prevention report found that in general the number of alcohol related crashes was reduced by 20 in states that implement sobriety checkpoints compared to those that do not
pair.h: Random sobriety tests for drivers are effective at deterring drunk driving

pair.t: Repeat drunk drivers unlikely to respond to random breath testing deterrence and One statistic the MAD bunch doesn t like to mention is the fact that half of the people killed by drunk drivers have at least double the legal blood alcohol limit and They don t like it because it implies that on a sliding scale drivers who are barely over the legal limit are probably not that bad and It suggests that problems associated with drunk driving are overwhelmingly caused by a small cadre of hard core problem drinkers who are sloshed behind the wheel and Unfortunately these are also the people who are the least responsive to legal incentives so MAD and the law targets ordinary people who have a glass or two of sherry instead
pair.h: Random alcohol breath tests reduce accidents save lives and The Centers for Disease Control in a 2002 Traffic Injury Prevention report found that in general the number of alcohol related crashes was reduced by 20 in states that implement sobriety checkpoints compared to those that do not

pair.t: Random alcohol tests are more effective than alternative measures and The federal Justice Department of Canada moved to implement Random Breath Testing RBT concluding a system of random checks is more effective than a combination of other measures such as a lower threshold for blood alcohol level and more frequent RIDE checkpoints
pair.h: Random sobriety tests for drivers are effective at deterring drunk driving

pair.t: The majority of people caught drink driving have not been from random breath tests and They have been from tip offs police chases and police pulling over suspects not random breath testing
pair.h: Random alcohol tests are more effective than alternative measures and The federal Justice Department of Canada moved to implement Random Breath Testing RBT concluding a system of random checks is more effective than a combination of other measures such as a lower threshold for blood alcohol level and more frequent RIDE checkpoints

pair.t: Releasing Bin Laden photos would inflame Muslim world White House Spokesman Jay Carney There are sensitivities here in terms of the appropriateness of releasing photographs in the aftermath of this firefight and It is fair to say they re gruesome photographs and It is certainly possible that it could be inflammatory
pair.h: Release of Osama bin Laden death photos incite Muslim reaction terrorism

pair.t: Photos won t upset extremists more than Laden s death and Wojtek Wolfe a Rutgers Camden professor I don’t know if it’s really going to make the situation any worse and It will upset some people but those people are already upset
pair.h: Release of Osama bin Laden death photos incite Muslim reaction terrorism

pair.t: US shouldn t kowtow to sensitivities of extremists and Obama and Rogers idea that news should be calibrated by the government to ease the job of the U and S and military makes for a First Amendment loophole you could drive a motorized regiment through and If al Qaida and its supporters are more irate with the United States this week than they were last week it s because U and S and commandos killed Bin Laden and Obama should never have marked him for death if tending the sensitivities of al Qaida and its allies was U and S and policy
pair.h: Release of Osama bin Laden death photos incite Muslim reaction terrorism

pair.t: Death photos destroy myth of Bin Laden s invulnerability
pair.h: Release of Osama bin Laden death photos incite Muslim reaction terrorism

pair.t: Death photos reveal Bin Laden as monster he was and The reason to display the photos is to show bin Laden for what he really was not a holy warrior not a holy anything but a deluded mass murderer who met the end he so richly deserved
pair.h: Death photos destroy myth of Bin Laden s invulnerability

pair.t: Releasing Bin Laden photos is a national security risk
pair.h: Release of Osama bin Laden death photos incite Muslim reaction terrorism

pair.t: Osama photos likely to provoke violence at US embassies and Secretary of State Hilary Clinton and Secretary of Defense Robert Gates vocally worried that the images would provoke anti American violence at embassies consulates and military bases overseas
pair.h: Releasing Bin Laden photos is a national security risk

pair.t: National security secrets not at risk in releasing Bin Laden photos and If national security secrets were revealed in the photos the equation would be different and But that s not the case with a single image of the terrorist leader s dead body
pair.h: Releasing Bin Laden photos is a national security risk

pair.t: Bin Laden death photos send warning to US enemies
pair.h: Release of Osama bin Laden death photos incite Muslim reaction terrorism

pair.t: Releasing the photos could deter would be jihadists who would have to think a little harder when they see the bloodied bodies of Osama s men killed in the firefight in his hideaway photos obtained by Reuters from a Pakistani security officer and rightly released on Wednesday
pair.h: Bin Laden death photos send warning to US enemies

pair.t: If Social Security were privatized people would deposit their income with a bank and People actually save resources that businesses can invest and We as true savers get more resources in the future
pair.h: Privatizing social security improves economic growth

pair.t: Creating private accounts could dampen economic growth which would further weaken social security s future finances and Privatizing Social Security will increase federal deficits and debt significantly while increasing the likelihood that national savings will decline
pair.h: If Social Security were privatized people would deposit their income with a bank and People actually save resources that businesses can invest and We as true savers get more resources in the future

pair.t: Social Security drains capital from the poorest areas of the country leaving less money available for new investment and job creation and Privatization would increase national savings and provide a new pool of capital for investment that would be particularly beneficial to the poor
pair.h: Privatizing social security improves economic growth

pair.t: Privatization would not increase capital for investment and The problem is that for every dollar put into the market through a private account the government would have to borrow a dollar in the market to cover existing payouts and Thus the supposed benefit is entirely eliminated as the net impact on the capital available for investment is zero
pair.h: Social Security drains capital from the poorest areas of the country leaving less money available for new investment and job creation and Privatization would increase national savings and provide a new pool of capital for investment that would be particularly beneficial to the poor

pair.t: Private accounts prevent politicians taking from social security
pair.h: Privatizing social security improves economic growth

pair.t: While Americans in retirement or approaching retirement would stay in the current system younger workers should have the option to invest a portion of their money in financial assets other than U and S and Treasuries and These accounts would be the ultimate lock box they would prevent politicians in Washington from raiding the Trust Fund and The truth is that taxpayers bailout politicians every year thanks to Social Security and Congress and the White House spend more money than they have so they steal money from Social Security to help pay for it and That needs to stop and there is no responsible way of doing that except with personal accounts
pair.h: Private accounts prevent politicians taking from social security

pair.t: Privatization during economic crisis would have been disaster and Privatization in the midst of the greatest economic downturn since the Great Depression would have caused households to have lost even more of their assets had their investments been invested in the U and S and stock market
pair.h: Privatizing social security improves economic growth

pair.t: Privatizing social security would wrongly enrich banks and Privatization would represent a windfall for Wall Street financial institutions who would obtain significant fees for managing private accounts
pair.h: Privatizing social security improves economic growth

pair.t: Diverting up to four percentage points of the payroll tax to create private accounts as the president has proposed would shorten significantly the time until the Trust Funds become depleted
pair.h: Privatizing social security improves economic growth

pair.t: The program is pay as you go meaning current payroll taxes pay for current retirees and Diverting to four percentage points of payroll taxes or other sources of government funds to fund private accounts would drive enormous deficits and borrowing transition costs
pair.h: Diverting up to four percentage points of the payroll tax to create private accounts as the president has proposed would shorten significantly the time until the Trust Funds become depleted

pair.t: Internet access is essential now must be a right and The internet is only that wire that delivers freedom of speech freedom of assembly and freedom of the press in a single connection
pair.h: Internet access is fundamental in modernity

pair.t: Just because something is a huge part in many people s lives does it mean that those things should be regarded as rights Cell phones for example and Should they become a right and If the internet is a right then cell phones should be rights because they are more common and Other examples like cars or even drugs and Drugs and cars are a huge part of people lives and Just because they re widespread and is used extensively doesn t mean that they should be rights
pair.h: Internet access is essential now must be a right and The internet is only that wire that delivers freedom of speech freedom of assembly and freedom of the press in a single connection

pair.t: Internet not as important as real rights and We may think of such trivial things as a fundamental right but consider the truly impoverished and what is most important to them and The right to vote the right to liberty and freedom from slavery or the right to elementary education and Perhaps it s time for a reality check and to re examine which of our rights are truly important
pair.h: Internet access is fundamental in modernity

pair.t: Internet access is essential to other human rights United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights includes the right to education and the right to work which may hinge on Internet access and And indeed The European Parliament has ruled that it sees internet access as critical for the practical exercise of a wide array of fundamental rights
pair.h: Internet access is fundamental in modernity

pair.t: I ve seen the growing awareness within the developing world that computers and connectivity matter and can be useful and It s not that computers matter more than water food shelter and healthcare but that the network and PCs can be used to ensure that those other things are available and Satellite imagery sent to a local computer can help villages find fresh water mobile phones can tell farmers the prices at market so they know when to harvest and The same arguments apply in the UK but those of us who have easy affordable and fast connectivity tend not to think of the plight of those who can t get online just as we so often fail to notice the homeless people in our towns or let our eyes glide over deprived housing estates as we sit on the train
pair.h: Internet not as important as real rights and We may think of such trivial things as a fundamental right but consider the truly impoverished and what is most important to them and The right to vote the right to liberty and freedom from slavery or the right to elementary education and Perhaps it s time for a reality check and to re examine which of our rights are truly important

pair.t: Internet access is not really essential and It is much easier than people think to live without the Internet and People were able to lead happy succesful lives in the past without the Internet and they are able to do so now as well and While there are certainly luxuries surrounding the use of the Internet it is excessive to deem it as essential to human life and happiness and It is excessive there to deem it as a fundamental human right on these grounds
pair.h: Internet access is fundamental in modernity

pair.t: Internet access is no right but means of entertainment and The Internet functions mostly as a means of entertainment enabling individuals to acquire information and to engage in other activities and No form of entertainment should be made a right
pair.h: Internet access is essential now must be a right and The internet is only that wire that delivers freedom of speech freedom of assembly and freedom of the press in a single connection

pair.t: In the U and S and if we are serious about equality of opportunity access to the Internet could be strongly defended as a human right
pair.h: Internet access is fundamental in modernity

pair.t: Some take for granted the idea that the Internet is good for humanity and Many people argue that it has had many negative impacts and The primary use of social networking sites is meforming or frequent updates about the minutia of people s lives that one research group duly categorized as pointless babble and And if the internet s most common asset is keeping us posted on what old high school classmates are having for brunch then its risks may be more important
pair.h: Internet access is no right but means of entertainment and The Internet functions mostly as a means of entertainment enabling individuals to acquire information and to engage in other activities and No form of entertainment should be made a right

pair.t: The internet is a right and It s in their enlightened self interest and And I will suggest that the WEF Global Agenda Council should catalogue quantify and demonstrate that self interest in terms of the benefit the internet brings a nation in 1 and business – jobs created efficiencies found innovation sparked entrepreneurism supported 2 and education – every human able to search all our digital knowledge distributed university curricula the growth of the aggregated education the pull toward literacy 3 and politics – the ability of citizens to coalesce and act the increase in involvement in politics the greater transparency enabled which some politicians will not think is in their self interest – but that is precisely why we will want this creed to separate democrats from dictators and the corrupt 4 and government – we have only begun to use connectivity to improve governance in its relationships with constituents and in efficiencies 4 and society – I argue in my book that staying connected may change the nature of relationships for the good – one to one and nation to nation
pair.h: Internet access is essential now must be a right and The internet is only that wire that delivers freedom of speech freedom of assembly and freedom of the press in a single connection

pair.t: Internet access in a time of democratized online publishing may be understood as a contemporary form of the right to self expression
pair.h: Internet access is fundamental in modernity

pair.t: Intentions of ground zero mosque developers are pure and State Department Spokesman P and J and Crowley said We have a long term relationship with Imam Faisal Abdul Rauf and His work on tolerance and religious diversity is well known and he brings a moderate perspective to foreign audiences on what it s like to be a practicing Muslim in the United States
pair.h: The intentions of Cordoba House also referred to as the Ground Zero Mosque developers are pure

pair.t: Cordoba House is a Muslim community center first mosque second and Only the top floor of the mosque will be a prayer space and Most of Ground Zero Mosque will act as a Muslim community center with a pool and exercise areas and spaces for other community related activities that have very little to do with prayer and This just dampens the idea that this is somehow a hard core or even radical religious institution and It simply is not
pair.h: The intentions of Cordoba House also referred to as the Ground Zero Mosque developers are pure

pair.t: Name Cordoba House indicates nefarious intent of mosque and The true intentions of Rauf are also revealed by the name initially proposed for the Ground Zero mosque— Cordoba House — which is named for a city in Spain where a conquering Muslim army replaced a church with a mosque
pair.h: Name Cordoba House is a very direct historical indication that the Ground Zero mosque is all about conquest and thus an assertion of Islamist triumphalism
